thread.title: College football: Army's offense out of sync against Duke
thread.title_full: College football: Army's offense out of sync against Duke

title: College football: Army's offense out of sync against Duke
text:
College football: Army's offense out of sync against Duke October 11, 2015 Last updated: Sunday, October 11, 2015, 1:21 AM STAFF AND WIRE REPORTS | Print 
Army West Point's triple option was victimized by three bad pitches that Duke converted into scores as the Black Knights fell, 44-3, Saturday at West Point, N.Y. 
The Duke defense limited Army (1-5) to 44 yards rushing on 26 carries in the decisive first half and 113 for game on 49 tries. Army entered averaging 287.8 yards rushing per game, 5.6 per carry. 
QB Thomas Sirk threw for 197 yards and one touchdown and Jela Duncan and Parker Boehme each scored twice as Duke (5-1) boosted its record to 11-1 in its last 12 road games. The Blue Devils are 5-1 in consecutive years for the first time since 1952-53. 
Army gave away the ball twice on consecutive possessions in the first half and trailed, 27-0, at halftime, never crossing midfield. The Army blunders came in a span of just over six minutes spanning the first and second quarters. 
"As agonizing as it is to lose, there's no time to feel sorry for yourself and sulk," Army coach Jeff Monken said. "You've got to move on." 
COLUMBIA 26, WAGNER 3 (at New York) — Cameron Molina ran for a touchdown and Max Keefe scored on a fumble return 16 seconds apart early in the first quarter as Columbia ended it 24-game losing streak. The Lions (1-3), who hadn't won since beating Cornell, 34-17, on Nov. 10, 2012, rolled to a 26-0 lead early in the second half in their first home game under the lights in 11 years. 
Molina capped a 15-play, 66-yard drive with a 6-yard run at 9:47. Wager (0-5) bobbled the snap on its next play and Keefe scooped up the bouncing ball at the 2 and stepped into the end zone. After QB Skyler Mornhinweg scampered 32 yards to put Columbia up 24-0 early in the second quarter, the Lions picked up a safety on the ensuing kickoff. 
UCONN 40, UCF 13 (at Orlando, Fla.) — Bryan Shirreffs threw for 256 yards and a TD and ran for another score as UConn (3-3, 1-1) halted a three-game losing streak with an American Athletic Conference win over UCF (0-6, 0-2). 
SOUTH FLORIDA 45, SYRACUSE 24 (at Tampa, Fla.) — Marlon Mack rushed for 179 yards and a pair of second-half TDs to help South Florida (2-3) end a three-game losing streak. Syracuse (3-2) lost for the second straight time after matching last year's win total in the first three weeks of this season. 
FORDHAM 48, PENN 45 (at Philadelphia) — Chase Edmonds rushed for 230 yards and scored four TDs but it was Makay Redd's 31-yard field goal with eight seconds left that lifted Fordham. 
Penn (1-4) tied it with 1:46 to play. But Kevin Anderson, who completed 29 of 36 passes for a career-high 377 yards and two touchdowns, took the Rams 51 yards in nine plays to set out the win. Robbie Cantelli had career-highs of 12 catches for 164 yards for Fordham (5-1). 
MONTCLAIR STATE 45, SOUTHERN VIRGINIA 0 (at Buena Vista, Va.) — QB Ryan Davies threw for two touchdowns and running backs Willie Barr, John DiStefano and Denzel Nieves each rushed for a TD as the Red Hawks rolled to their second straight win. 
FROSTBURG STATE (Md.) 37, WILLIAM PATERSON 19 (at Wayne) — The Pioneers rallied to tie the game less than a minute into the second half, but Frostburg State took control during William Paterson's homecoming game at Wightman Stadium. Frostburg State QB Connor Cox was 13 of 16 passing for 142 yards and two TDs, and rushed for another TD. 
PRINCETON 44, COLGATE 20 (at Princeton) — John Lovett had four rushing touchdowns to help Princeton (4-0) stay unbeaten. 
CHARLESTON SOUTHERN 37, MONMOUTH 7 (at Charleston, S.C.) — Mike Holloway rushed for three touchdowns and the Charleston Southern defense allowed Monmouth just 115 total yards in a Big South matchup. 
WAKE FOREST 3, BOSTON COLLEGE 0 (at Boston) — Mike Weaver kicked a 25-yard field goal after Wake Forest forced a turnover deep in BC's territory, and the Demon Deacons snapped a two-game losing streak (3-3, 1-2 ACC). The Eagles (3-3, 0-3) have lost three straight. © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
